citation.article-title: Dietzia aerolata sp. nov., isolated from the air of a duck barn, and emended description of the genus Dietzia Rainey et al. 1995
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Dietzia aerolata sp. nov.
Dietzia aerolata (ae.ro.la′ta. Gr. n. aer air; L. fem. part. adj. lata carried; N.L. fem. part. adj. aerolata airborne).
Coccoid cells, approximately 1–1.5 μm in diameter.
Gram-stain-positive, oxidase-positive, catalase-positive showing an oxidative metabolism.
Good growth occurs after 3 days of incubation on R2A agar and nutrient agar at 25–30 °C.
The quinone system contains MK-8 [H2] predominantly.
The major polar lipids are diphosphatidylglycerol, phosphatidylglycerol, two unknown glycolipids and three unknown polar lipids.
Phosphatidylinositol and two phosphatidylinositol mannosides as well as two unknown aminolipids and several unknown polar lipids are detectable.
The polyamine pattern contains the major compounds spermine and spermidine.
Major fatty acids are C16 : 0, C17 : 0, C18 : 1ω9c and 10-methyl C18 : 0.
Carbon source utilizations (including differentiating characteristics under identical conditions) are indicated in Table 1.
d-Glucose and d-mannose are utilized, but many other sugar compounds are not utilized.
The type strain is Sj14aT (=DSM 45334T =CCM 7659T), which was isolated from the air of a duck barn.
